stage.name: VALIDATING
stage.title: Product / Market Fit
stage.goal: Prove people will pay for your solution and keep using it
stage.subtitle: Revenue is the ultimate validation. Everything else is vanity.

lines: Your product is live. Congratulations - you've built something.
But building is the easy part. Now you need to prove people will PAY.
In this stage, you'll face rejection, objections, and hard truths.
How you handle them will determine if this becomes a real business.

stageEndCheck.convergenceLogic: AI ensures C8, C9, C10 fully assessed before stage completion

questions.questionText: Your product is LIVE. Month 3. How will you get your first 10 paying customers?
questions.narrativeIntro: This is where most startups die. Getting those first customers is brutal. How will you do it?

scenario.context: You have a functional product but zero customers. Your runway is {{runway}} months. Every day without customers is a day closer to failure.
scenario.stakes: Your acquisition strategy sets the tone for your entire go-to-market approach.

options.text: Cold outreach - email and LinkedIn to prospects
options.insight: Takes courage but works. High rejection rate.

options.text: Run paid ads (Google, Facebook, etc.)

followUp.questionText: How much will you spend on ads this month?

options.text: Leverage personal network and ask for referrals
Create content marketing (blog, social, YouTube)
options.insight: Long-term play. Won't show results immediately.

options.text: Partner with existing businesses who serve your customers

questions.questionText: What's your pricing? How much will customers pay, and WHY that specific number?
questions.narrativeIntro: Pricing reveals how much you understand your value. Most founders undercharge.
questions.helpText: Consider: competitor prices, value delivered, customer's willingness to pay, your costs, and desired margins.

aiEvaluation.systemPrompt: Evaluate pricing strategy. Look for value-based thinking, competitive awareness, margin consideration, and justification.

questions.questionText: A prospect says: "Your competitor charges 30% less. Why should I pay more?"
questions.narrativeIntro: Price objections are inevitable. How you handle them reveals your sales skills.

scenario.context: You're in a sales conversation with a qualified prospect who's comparing you to a cheaper alternative.
scenario.stakes: Win the deal at full price, or set a precedent of discounting.

options.text: Match the competitor's price
options.warning: WARNING: Racing to the bottom destroys margins

options.text: Explain the superior value you provide

followUp.questionText: Specifically, what would you say to justify the higher price?

options.text: Offer an early-adopter discount
options.insight: Reasonable compromise, but be careful of precedent

options.text: Let them go - they're not the right customer
options.insight: Sometimes the best deal is no deal

questions.narrativeIntro: Let's see how your first month of sales went.

decisionRequired.questionText: Based on this feedback, what's your MONTH 4 priority?

options.text: Focus on retention - improve the experience for existing customers
options.insight: SMART: Keep what you have before getting more

options.text: Double down on acquisition - get more customers
options.warning: WARNING: Leaky bucket problem - more in, more out

options.text: Build feature X that customers requested
options.insight: Responsive to feedback - good if it's the right feature

options.text: Talk to ALL customers personally to understand deeply

questions.questionText: URGENT: A customer reports a critical bug that's breaking their workflow. Meanwhile, you have a big sales meeting tomorrow that you haven't prepared for. What do you do?
questions.narrativeIntro: Welcome to startup life. Everything is urgent, and you can't do everything.

scenario.context: It's 6 PM. The bug will take about 2 days to fix. The sales meeting could bring in a customer worth 3x your average deal.
scenario.stakes: This decision reveals your priorities and how you handle conflicting demands.

options.text: Fix the bug immediately - existing customers first
Prepare for the sales meeting - bigger opportunity
options.warning: WARNING: Existing customer may churn and leave bad review

options.text: Split time between both
Communicate with both, prioritize bug, reschedule sales meeting

questions.questionText: MONTH 5: You now have 50 customers and $10,000 monthly revenue. You spent $5,000 on marketing. What is your Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC)?
questions.narrativeIntro: Unit economics 101. If you don't know your CAC, you're flying blind.

educationalFeedback.ifCorrect: Correct! $100 CAC. Now the question is: is that sustainable?
educationalFeedback.ifWrong: CAC = Marketing Spend รท New Customers Acquired. $5,000 รท 50 = $100 per customer.

questions.questionText: Your numbers: Average revenue per customer: ${{arpc}}, CAC: ${{cac}}, Gross margin: {{margin}}%. You are currently {{profitability_status}}.
questions.narrativeIntro: Unit economics determine whether growth helps or hurts you.

ifProfitable.questionText: Your unit economics are healthy. What do you do?

options.text: Aggressively scale marketing - pour fuel on the fire
Optimize margins further before scaling

ifUnprofitable.questionText: You're losing money on each customer. What do you do?

options.text: PAUSE new acquisition and fix the economics
options.insight: BEST: Stop the bleeding before it kills you

options.text: Raise prices
Cut costs aggressively
Keep growing - we'll figure it out later
options.warning: CRITICAL: This is how startups die

questions.questionText:
MONTH 6 CRISIS: Three things hit at once:
1) Your biggest customer (20% of revenue) threatens to leave unless you build a custom feature
2) Five smaller customers report the same bug
3) A major prospect wants a demo TODAY or they'll go with competitor
questions.narrativeIntro: This is entrepreneurship. Everything breaks at once. How do you handle it?

scenario.context: You have limited resources. Choosing one means neglecting others.
scenario.stakes: This tests your prioritization under extreme pressure.

options.text: Build custom feature for major customer
options.warning: WARNING: Custom work derails product vision

options.text: Fix the bug for the 5 customers
options.insight: GOOD: Serve the many over the one

options.text: Do the sales demo - biggest opportunity
Delegate and handle multiple priorities

condition.failMessage: You're solo - you can't delegate what you don't have

options.insight: BEST IF POSSIBLE: This is why you build a team

options.text: Have honest conversations with all three, set expectations, prioritize bug
options.insight: MATURE: Transparency builds trust even when you can't do everything

format.positiveSignals: List specific decisions that showed competency
format.negativeSignals: List specific decisions that showed weakness

stageTransition.narrativeIntro: You've validated that people will pay. Now comes the harder question: can you scale without breaking everything you've built?

timeAdvance.narrative: Four months of intense customer work. You're at Month 7 now. Time to think about scaling.
